item.title: Ticket #3246 (make menu items in menu-headers.php relative) updated
item.dc:creator: Sewar
item.description:
Keywords changed

You can use ​Secure Admin which used in WordPress.Com, see: ​http://wordpress.com/blog/2006/03/08/secure-blogging/.

item.title: Ticket #2864 (Magpie falling behind feed developments) reopened
item.dc:creator: matt
item.description:
This is entirely unacceptable.

We just broke everything that uses our RSS libraries in the world. If simplepie can't maintain the same external functions, like fetch_rss and the old object structure, then we shouldn't use it. Nothing in WP should have changed except the library.

Also, the dashboard is now loading entire posts rather than descriptions.

item.title: Changeset [4398]: Bring a little love to the oft-neglected email comment approval page.

item.description: Bring a little love to the oft-neglected email comment approval page.

item.title: menu-header.php.diff attached to Ticket #3246
item.dc:creator: bmontgom
item.description: patch for menu-headers.php

item.title: Ticket #3246 (make menu items in menu-headers.php relative) created
item.dc:creator: bmontgom
item.description: The URIs for the menu items in menu-headers.php are not relative URIs. These are the only URIs on the page that are not this way. I've been working on a plugin to allow for the login, register, and admin functions to be done using SSL. It is working, but I had to modify menu-headers.php to make the menu item URIs relative in order to get everything correct. A patch for my changes is attached.

item.title: Ticket #3245 (Inline Uploader Improvements: search and filters) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Status changed

I knew what you meant. :-)

I think this would be of use to the majority of people who use the inline uploader.

item.description: Patch for trunk

item.title: Ticket #3244 (tiny i18n fix) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Owner, Status changed

Hm, don't think so. And for more than one, we need to use __ngettext()

See patch. I also re-ordered the logic, removed the last test (after all, if a positive integer isn't greater than one, and isn't zero, it MUST be one), and passed the number of comments to the filter at the end, to make it easier for plugin authors to use the filter (no need to preg_match() the number).

item.title: Ticket #679 (Uploading a file with metaweblog protocol xmlrpc leads to corrupted ...) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description: As commented on ​http://trac.wordpress.org/ticket/1008#comment:9 this works fine and is not a bug.

item.title: Ticket #1008 (metaWeblog API enhancements for WordPress - enclosure support) closed
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
worksforme:

This is _not_ a bug.

The base64 information provided by the client is decoded by the XML-RPC client code in class-IXR.php before the function in xml-rpc.php is called.

This happens here - ​http://trac.wordpress.org/browser/branches/2.0/wp-includes/class-IXR.php#L221 when the parent class parses the incoming XML-RPC message.

I have tested this for both the metaweblog api and moveabletype api and it works fine for me (using ​http://www.blogdesk.org)

item.title: Ticket #3245 (Inline Uploader Improvements: search and filters) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Users with a lot of uploaded images would benefit from the following:

  • Search (could be a new tab next to browse).
  • Filter for postsperpage setting on browse tab (default is 10)

People who reuse old images need to be able to find the images they want.

item.title: Ticket #3237 (Increase number of post-meta keys to 30 and sort them) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Owner, Status changed

I like this. It'll only matter for people who have more than 10 keys, and those people probably want to see them for easier access.

30 is a reasonable number. I can also implement the filter suggestion from #1865 , so people can easily change it.

See patch.

item.title: Ticket #3243 (Usermeta and postmeta functions assume data to be pre-escaped) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: Status, Description changed

item.title: Ticket #3243 (Usermeta and postmeta functions assume data to be pre-escaped) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
User meta functions assume that data passed to them is already escaped ( $wpdb->escape()

Post meta functions assume data is not already escaped.

I think we should move to a standardized way of doing this, and I think the standard should be to expect unescaped data.

  1. It is safer.
    • Worst case scenario with assuming data to be unescaped is that it gets double slashed
    • Worst case scenario with assuming data to be escaped is SQL injection vulnerability
  2. Post meta has been doing it this way, for a longer time, so less code would have to change
  3. It would allow code consolidation, in terms of handling arrays/objects/strings, serialization, and escape.
  4. Currently, things like First Name and Last Name are passed through filters pre-slashed, which means that filters have to work around this.

Setting a milestone of 2.2

We can do this in trunk right after 2.1 ships, so that plugin authors will have 4 months to adapt.
